title: Cyber Security (Amendment) Bill
summary:
The Cyber Security (Amendment) Bill fundamentally transforms Ghana's Cybersecurity Authority from a regulatory body into a comprehensive law enforcement and certification agency. The bill **expands the Authority's core functions** to include investigating and prosecuting cybercrimes with Attorney-General approval, while granting its officers **police powers** including arrest, search, and seizure authority ([2](#2-section-4a-inserted), [8](#8-section-20b-inserted)). The Authority gains **asset confiscation powers** to seize property obtained through cybercrime and pursue civil asset recovery, subject to court confirmation ([24](#24-section-59b-inserted)). These enforcement capabilities are supported by **extensive investigative tools**: court-ordered data production from service providers ([26](#26-section-59d-inserted), [27](#27-section-59e-inserted)), search warrants for computer systems ([28](#28-section-59f-inserted)), and data preservation orders lasting up to 90 days with one renewal ([30](#30-section-59h-inserted), [31](#31-section-59i)). The bill establishes **judicial oversight mechanisms** requiring officers to demonstrate reasonable cause, proportionality, and privacy protections for uninvolved parties when seeking court orders.

The bill creates a **comprehensive licensing and certification regime** that regulates the entire cybersecurity ecosystem. All cybersecurity service providers—whether for-profit or non-profit—must obtain licenses or accreditation, with violations carrying penalties of 50,000-100,000 penalty units or damages plus financial gains ([15](#15-section-49-of-act-1038-amended)). Individual cybersecurity professionals must be **accredited to practice**, and engaging unaccredited professionals triggers administrative penalties ([16](#16-section-57-of-act-1038-amended)). The Authority will establish **certification schemes** for emerging technologies including AI, blockchain, cloud computing, quantum computing, and big data ([20](#20-section-58a-inserted), [22](#22-section-59-of-act-1038-amended)). A notable provision standardizes fees for cyber hygiene certification services and **requires certified professionals to contribute 30% of their revenue** to the cybersecurity fund ([19](#19-section-57c-inserted)). While this framework aims to ensure quality standards and professional competence, it creates **significant compliance requirements** for businesses and practitioners, potentially raising operational costs and creating barriers to market entry for smaller providers.

The bill substantially enhances **funding for cybersecurity operations** through multiple revenue streams: 12% of communications service tax, 9% of corporate tax, portions of fines, licensing fees, and charges on government e-services ([9](#9-section-31-of-act-1038-amended)). Critical information infrastructure owners face **mandatory registration requirements** with associated fees and must report cybersecurity incidents within specified timeframes ([11](#11-section-36-of-act-1038-amended)). Sectoral Computer Emergency Response Teams must report incidents to the National CERT **within 24 hours** or face administrative penalties ([14](#14-section-47-of-act-1038-amended)). The Authority can conduct **premises inspections** without warrants (except for homes) with reasonable cause and prior notice ([32](#32-section-59j)). These provisions create a robust incident response framework but impose **ongoing compliance obligations** on infrastructure owners and businesses, including audit requirements and directive compliance with financial penalties for violations.

The bill introduces **significant online safety protections** while expanding criminal liability. New offenses include **cyberbullying and online harassment**—covering threatening messages, fake profiles, non-consensual tracking, and spreading false information—with penalties of 1-10 years imprisonment ([35](#35-section-67a-inserted)). **Cyberstalking** becomes a distinct crime with similar penalties ([36](#36-section-67b-inserted)). The bill criminalizes **computer-related forgery** (intentionally altering data to create fake information for legal use) and **computer-related fraud** (causing property loss through data manipulation or system interference), both prosecuted under existing fraud laws ([43](#43-section-94a-inserted), [44](#44-section-94b-inserted)). Enhanced penalties apply to existing cybercrimes, with imprisonment now ranging from 3-10 years and fines from 250-25,000 penalty units ([34](#34-section-67-of-act-1038-amended), [37](#37-section-68-of-act-1038-amended)). The bill includes **witness protection provisions** requiring the Authority to maintain confidentiality of informants and ensure their safety ([33](#33-section-59k-inserted)). While these provisions strengthen protections for vulnerable groups—particularly children, for whom service providers must implement protective measures—they also **expand the scope of criminal liability** for online activities, raising questions about enforcement discretion and potential impacts on digital expression.

description.analysis:
This bill creates a **comprehensive regulatory framework that fundamentally constrains digital innovation** in Ghana by requiring mandatory certification for all emerging technologies. The Authority gains power to **certify the security of AI, blockchain, cloud technology, quantum computing, big data, and IoT** before deployment ([2](#2-section-4a-inserted), [22](#22-section-59-of-act-1038-amended)). This pre-approval requirement transforms Ghana's innovation ecosystem from a permissionless environment into one where **every new technology must pass through a centralized regulatory bottleneck**. The Authority can issue binding directives to "innovators, developers, service providers" ([41](#41-section-92-of-act-1038-amended)), giving it broad discretion to shape or restrict technological development. For startups and technology companies, this creates significant **time-to-market delays** and regulatory uncertainty that could deter investment and experimentation with cutting-edge technologies.

The **financial burden on innovation is substantial and multi-layered**. All cybersecurity service providers—including tech startups offering security solutions—must obtain licenses or face penalties of 50,000-100,000 penalty units ([15](#15-section-49-of-act-1038-amended)). Individual cybersecurity professionals and practitioners must be accredited, with penalties for both unlicensed practice and for engaging unlicensed practitioners ([16](#16-section-57-of-act-1038-amended)). Most significantly, certified professionals must **contribute 30% of their revenue to the cybersecurity fund** ([19](#19-section-57c-inserted))—effectively a 30% tax on innovation services that dramatically reduces profitability and competitiveness. Combined with licensing fees, compliance costs, and mandatory audits, these requirements create **substantial barriers to entry** that favor established players over innovative startups and could drive talent and companies to more permissive jurisdictions.

The **enforcement regime poses serious risks** for innovators and technology companies. Criminal penalties of up to 5 years imprisonment apply for operating without licenses, failing to comply with directives, or violating cybersecurity standards ([23](#23-section-59a-inserted)). Enhanced penalties for unauthorized access to critical infrastructure—including mere attempts—carry 2-5 years imprisonment and fines up to 25,000 penalty units ([42](#42-section-94-of-act-1038-amended)). The cyberstalking and harassment provisions ([36](#36-section-67b-inserted), [37](#37-section-68-of-act-1038-amended)) create **legal uncertainty for social media platforms, online gaming companies, and virtual reality developers** who must now police user behavior or face potential liability. The Authority's police powers ([8](#8-section-20b-inserted)) and broad regulatory mandate ([40](#40-section-91-of-act-1038-amended)) create an environment where **innovation activities carry significant legal risk**, potentially chilling experimentation and the rapid iteration cycles essential to technology development.

The Cyber Security (Amendment) Bill poses **severe threats to freedom of speech** in Ghana's digital ecosystem through expansive criminalization of online expression coupled with vague legal standards and harsh penalties. The bill's cyberbullying and online harassment provisions ([35](#35-section-67a-inserted)) criminalize a broad spectrum of online communications using ill-defined terms such as **"offensive," "rude," "insulting," and "derogatory"** content. Most concerning is the prohibition on using electronic devices to "deliberately spread false or misleading information with the intent to deceive or manipulate a person or a fact"—language so broad it could encompass political satire, contested factual claims, opinion journalism, or any speech deemed misleading by authorities. The **cyberstalking provisions** ([36](#36-section-67b-inserted)) similarly criminalize creating or posting "false information" about a person, raising questions about how "false" will be determined and whether this could be weaponized against critics, journalists, or political opponents. While protecting children and vulnerable adults from genuine harassment is legitimate, these provisions extend far beyond that narrow purpose to regulate adult-to-adult communications with criminal sanctions.

The **severity of penalties** amplifies the chilling effect on digital expression. Violations carry imprisonment terms of **1-10 years** and fines ranging from 100 to 25,000 penalty units ([35](#35-section-67a-inserted), [36](#36-section-67b-inserted), [37](#37-section-68-of-act-1038-amended)). These are not minor administrative penalties but serious criminal sanctions that could devastate individuals' lives and livelihoods. The threat of such severe punishment will inevitably cause citizens, journalists, activists, and ordinary social media users to **self-censor** rather than risk prosecution for speech that might be deemed "offensive" or "misleading" by authorities. The grant of **police powers to Cybersecurity Authority officers** ([8](#8-section-20b-inserted))—including arrest, search, and seizure authority—means these speech-related offenses can be enforced directly by a regulatory agency without traditional police oversight, creating additional concerns about selective enforcement and abuse of power.

The bill's impact is particularly severe because it lacks **adequate safeguards and clear definitions**. Terms like "offensive," "embarrassing," "manipulate," and "false information" are inherently subjective and context-dependent, yet the bill provides no clear standards for their application. This vagueness violates fundamental principles of legal certainty—citizens cannot know in advance what speech is prohibited. The provisions also lack meaningful exceptions for journalism, political speech, satire, or good-faith errors, and contain no requirement that prosecutors prove actual harm or malicious intent beyond the vague "intent to deceive." While the bill includes some legitimate protections—such as requiring service providers to protect children from online violence—the **overall framework prioritizes content control over free expression**, creating a legal environment where digital speech is presumptively risky and subject to expansive criminal liability. This represents a fundamental shift in Ghana's approach to online expression, with potentially profound consequences for democratic discourse, investigative journalism, and citizens' ability to freely communicate and organize in digital spaces.

The Cyber Security (Amendment) Bill creates a **complex privacy landscape** that significantly expands government data access capabilities while implementing judicial safeguards. The most substantial privacy concern stems from [8](#8-section-20b-inserted), which grants Cybersecurity Authority officers **full police powers** including arrest, search, and seizure authority. This provision fundamentally transforms the privacy environment by creating a new enforcement apparatus with broad investigative powers over digital systems and data. Citizens will face surveillance and data access from an expanded set of government actors beyond traditional law enforcement, increasing the overall scope of state access to private information.

However, the bill incorporates **meaningful privacy protections** through judicial oversight mechanisms. [29](#29-section-59g-inserted) requires courts to verify that data requests are "commensurate, proportionate and necessary" before granting warrants, and mandates that investigators implement measures to "maintain the privacy of other users, customers and third parties" not involved in investigations. This proportionality requirement and protection for uninvolved parties represents a **significant safeguard** against overreach, ensuring that data collection is targeted rather than indiscriminate. The requirement for court approval creates an independent check on investigative authority, though the effectiveness depends on judicial capacity and willingness to scrutinize requests rigorously.

The **emergency disclosure provision** in [38](#38-section-83-of-act-1038-amended) introduces concerning flexibility by allowing "expedited disclosure of specified stored computer data" from service providers without mutual assistance requests in situations involving "significant and imminent risk to life or safety." While this serves legitimate public safety purposes, it creates a **fast-track mechanism** for data access that bypasses normal procedural protections. The broad definition of "emergency" could potentially be interpreted expansively, and the lack of prior judicial authorization in these circumstances represents a meaningful reduction in privacy protection. Overall, the bill expands surveillance infrastructure substantially while implementing partial safeguards that mitigate but do not eliminate privacy risks.

The Cyber Security (Amendment) Bill imposes **severe operational and financial burdens** on Ghana's business environment through a comprehensive regulatory framework that affects virtually all digitally-engaged businesses. The bill establishes **mandatory licensing for all cybersecurity service providers** and **accreditation requirements for individual practitioners**, with violations carrying penalties of 50,000-100,000 penalty units or damages plus financial gains ([15](#15-section-49-of-act-1038-amended), [16](#16-section-57-of-act-1038-amended)). Businesses engaging unaccredited professionals face administrative penalties of 250-20,000 penalty units, creating liability risks for hiring decisions. Most significantly, the bill requires **certified professionals to contribute 30% of their revenue** to the cybersecurity fund ([19](#19-section-57c-inserted))—an unprecedented extraction that will substantially reduce profitability for cybersecurity businesses and likely be passed on to clients as higher service costs. The Authority will also establish **certification schemes for emerging technologies** including AI, blockchain, cloud computing, and quantum computing ([2](#2-section-4a-inserted)), requiring businesses to obtain certifications before deploying these innovations, potentially slowing technology adoption and increasing implementation costs.

**Critical infrastructure owners face extensive compliance obligations** including mandatory registration with annual fees, detailed reporting requirements, and 7-day notification of ownership changes ([11](#11-section-36-of-act-1038-amended)). The bill's funding mechanisms directly increase business costs through **9% of corporate tax and 12% of communications service tax** dedicated to the cybersecurity fund, alongside charges on financial institutions licensed by the Bank of Ghana and fees on government e-services ([9](#9-section-31-of-act-1038-amended)). These provisions create **recurring financial obligations** that will affect business profitability across sectors. The Authority gains broad powers to issue directives to service providers, innovators, and developers ([41](#41-section-92-of-act-1038-amended)), with non-compliance triggering administrative penalties, cease-and-desist orders, license suspensions, or criminal prosecution with up to 5 years imprisonment and 20,000 penalty units in fines ([23](#23-section-59a-inserted)). Corporate entities face the same fines, with each director deemed to have committed the offense.

The **enforcement framework creates significant regulatory risk** for businesses. The Authority's officers receive **police powers** including arrest, search, and seizure authority ([8](#8-section-20b-inserted)), enabling direct intervention in business operations during investigations. Enhanced criminal penalties for cybercrimes now range from 3-10 years imprisonment with fines of 250-25,000 penalty units ([37](#37-section-68-of-act-1038-amended), [42](#42-section-94-of-act-1038-amended)), creating substantial liability exposure for businesses whose systems are compromised or misused. The bill establishes **multiple layers of regulatory requirements**—licensing, accreditation, certification, registration, reporting, and directive compliance—each with associated costs and penalties ([40](#40-section-91-of-act-1038-amended)). While these provisions aim to strengthen Ghana's cybersecurity posture, they create **substantial barriers to market entry** for smaller businesses and startups, increase operational costs across the digital economy, and introduce regulatory complexity that may discourage investment and innovation. The cumulative effect is a **significantly more expensive and complex business environment** for technology companies, cybersecurity providers, and any business operating digital infrastructure.

keyConcerns.title: Vague "False Information" Crime Criminalizes Speech
keyConcerns.description: This provision makes it a crime to **"create false information about a person"** or **"post or disseminate false information about a person"** with penalties of **1-10 years imprisonment**. The terms "false information," "harass," and "stalk" are undefined, creating legal uncertainty about what speech is prohibited. The provision contains **no exceptions** for truth, good faith, opinion, satire, journalism, or public interest—protections fundamental to free speech in democratic societies. This broad criminalization with severe penalties creates a **chilling effect** on legitimate online expression including criticism, investigative journalism, whistleblowing, and academic debate. The overlap with [35](#35-section-67a-inserted) allows prosecutors to select between 1-3 year or 1-10 year penalties for similar conduct based on discretion rather than clear legal criteria.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Certification Gatekeeps Emerging Technologies
keyConcerns.description: The Authority gains power to **establish mandatory certification schemes** for AI, blockchain, quantum computing, big data, and IoT technologies, while requiring **accreditation of all cybersecurity professionals and service providers**. When combined with the bill's penalties for engaging unaccredited professionals ([16](#16-section-57-of-act-1038-amended)), this creates a **government approval requirement** before deploying innovative technologies—transforming the Authority into a gatekeeper that could delay or block technology adoption. This regulatory burden is particularly problematic for startups and innovators who typically rely on rapid experimentation and iteration, potentially **stifling Ghana's digital innovation ecosystem** by requiring government approval at every stage of technology development and deployment.

keyConcerns.title: Accreditation Regime Restricts Cybersecurity Market Entry
keyConcerns.description: The Authority gains power to **accredit all cybersecurity establishments, service providers, practitioners and professionals** (4A(d)-(e)), converting what is typically an unregulated service sector in democracies into a licensed profession. Combined with penalties for engaging unaccredited professionals ([16](#16-section-57-of-act-1038-amended)) and mandatory licensing fees ([15](#15-section-49-of-act-1038-amended)), this creates **significant barriers to market entry** for cybersecurity businesses and restricts organizations' ability to hire cybersecurity talent. The provision establishes no explicit standards for accreditation decisions or appeal mechanisms, creating uncertainty for businesses seeking to enter or operate in Ghana's cybersecurity market.

keyConcerns.title: Regulatory Agency Gains Police Powers
keyConcerns.description: The provision grants **arrest, search, and seizure authority** to the same agency that licenses cybersecurity businesses and certifies emerging technologies. This concentration creates **enforcement uncertainty** for technology companies and innovators—regulatory disputes over licensing or certification could escalate to arrests and asset seizures by the same entity. The combination of regulatory control over market entry and police powers, without institutional separation, **deters innovation and investment** by creating governance risks not found in mature technology markets.

keyConcerns.title: Regulatory Agency Can Arrest for Speech
keyConcerns.description: This provision grants **Cybersecurity Authority officers police powers** including arrest, search, and seizure authority—the same powers as Police Officers under Ghana's criminal procedure laws. When combined with the bill's new **cyberbullying and online harassment offenses** (which criminalize "spreading false information" and "threatening messages"), this creates a severe **chilling effect on online expression**. Unlike independent police who operate under parliamentary oversight, Authority officers answer to a Director-General appointed by the President and can arrest individuals for speech offenses based on their own assessment, without independent review. This concentration of regulatory, investigative, and enforcement powers over online speech in a single agency violates democratic norms requiring separation of these functions.

keyConcerns.title: Surveillance Powers Without Privacy Oversight
keyConcerns.description: The provision grants **arrest, search, and seizure powers** to Authority officers who already control extensive data access mechanisms including production orders ([26](#26-section-59d-inserted), [27](#27-section-59e-inserted)), computer system searches ([28](#28-section-59f-inserted)), and 90-day data preservation ([30](#30-section-59h-inserted)). This concentration creates a **surveillance apparatus without independent oversight**—the same agency that compels service providers to produce user data can now arrest individuals and conduct searches, all while receiving **50% of criminal fines** ([9](#9-section-31-of-act-1038-amended)) that incentivize enforcement. Unlike independent police services with established privacy safeguards and judicial oversight, the Authority operates as a regulatory body with **no privacy-specific limits** on how these powers interact with its data access capabilities.

keyConcerns.title: Regulator Gains Arrest Powers Over Licensees
keyConcerns.description: The Cybersecurity Authority—which **licenses and regulates cybersecurity businesses**—gains police powers to **arrest, search, and seize** from the same entities it regulates. Combined with the Authority receiving **50% of criminal fines** ([9](#9-section-31-of-act-1038-amended)), this creates a conflict of interest where a regulator with financial incentives from enforcement can arrest licensees' employees and search their premises. This concentration of regulatory and law enforcement powers in a single agency undermines predictable business operations and creates risks of discriminatory enforcement.

keyConcerns.title: Authority Profits from Enforcement Fines
keyConcerns.description: The provision allocates **50% of all criminal fines** directly to the Authority's operational fund, creating a direct financial incentive for the agency to maximize prosecutions and penalties. Combined with the Authority's **police and prosecution powers** granted in [8](#8-section-20b-inserted), this violates separation of powers principles—the same entity investigates, prosecutes, and profits from convictions. For businesses, this creates **unpredictable enforcement risk** where regulatory decisions may be driven by revenue targets rather than genuine cybersecurity threats, undermining investor confidence in fair, proportionate treatment.

keyConcerns.title: Unconstrained Registration Fees and Requirements
keyConcerns.description: The Authority can unilaterally set **annual registration fees** for critical information infrastructure owners "as determined by the Authority" with no specified limits or proportionality requirements. Combined with [10](#10-section-35-of-act-1038-amended)'s broad CII definition (including "digital services" and ministerial discretion), this could capture businesses unexpectedly. The Authority also determines "**any other matter relating to registration**" through guidelines—creating unpredictable compliance obligations without parliamentary oversight or exemptions for smaller operators.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Licensing Blocks Market Entry
keyConcerns.description: This provision requires **all cybersecurity service providers** to obtain licenses from the Authority before offering services "for a reward," with penalties of **50,000-100,000 penalty units** or damages plus financial gains for violations. Combined with [16](#16-section-57-of-act-1038-amended) requiring individual practitioner accreditation, this creates a **dual-layer gatekeeping regime** that significantly raises barriers to market entry for startups, independent consultants, and smaller providers. The provision lacks defined licensing criteria, timelines, or appeal mechanisms, creating **discretionary government control** over who can participate in the cybersecurity market—a departure from OECD norms where such services operate in competitive markets with minimal pre-market licensing.

keyConcerns.title: Severe Penalties Without Defined Licensing Criteria
keyConcerns.description: The provision imposes **mandatory licensing** for all cybersecurity service providers with penalties of **50,000-100,000 penalty units** (or damages plus financial gains) for violations, yet **fails to specify licensing criteria, timelines, or appeal procedures**. This creates severe regulatory uncertainty for businesses: providers cannot determine what standards they must meet to obtain licenses, how long approval will take, or how to challenge adverse decisions. The penalty structure makes no distinction between minor administrative violations and serious breaches, treating all unlicensed provision equally. Combined with [16](#16-section-57-of-act-1038-amended) requiring individual accreditation, this creates a **dual-layer compliance burden** that significantly increases operational costs and market entry barriers, particularly for smaller providers and consultants.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Accreditation Gatekeeps Cybersecurity Innovation
keyConcerns.description: This provision requires **all cybersecurity professionals and practitioners to obtain Authority accreditation** before practicing, with penalties of 250-20,000 penalty units for violations. The requirement creates **significant barriers to market entry** for new practitioners, startups, and independent consultants who must obtain government approval before offering services. Combined with the organizational licensing requirement in [15](#15-section-49-of-act-1038-amended), this establishes a **dual-layer gatekeeping system** unusual in technology sectors. The undefined scope of "cybersecurity professional or practitioner" could capture security researchers, educators, or consultants, **chilling innovation and informal knowledge-sharing**. The provision lacks criteria for accreditation, appeal mechanisms, or recognition of international qualifications, concentrating discretionary power in the Authority without transparent standards.

keyConcerns.title: Dual Accreditation Burden Restricts Market Access
keyConcerns.description: This provision requires **all cybersecurity professionals to obtain Authority accreditation** before practicing, while simultaneously **prohibiting businesses from engaging unaccredited practitioners** (250-20,000 penalty units). Combined with the preceding [licensing requirement for service providers](#15-section-49-of-act-1038-amended) (50,000-100,000 penalty units), this creates a **two-tier regulatory system** unprecedented in OECD democracies where cybersecurity is typically unregulated. Businesses face cascading compliance obligations: verifying practitioner accreditation status, maintaining documentation, and bearing liability for engaging unaccredited individuals - creating operational costs and market access barriers that restrict competition and raise service delivery costs.

keyConcerns.title: Price Controls Stifle Service Innovation
keyConcerns.description: This provision mandates **government-set flat rates** for cyber hygiene certification services and requires certified providers to **contribute 30% of revenue** to the cybersecurity fund. This combination eliminates pricing flexibility, prevents service differentiation, and significantly reduces profitability—creating substantial barriers to market entry for startups and disincentives for investment in improved services. The Authority's dual role in both setting prices and collecting revenue creates a **financial conflict of interest** that undermines neutral regulation and market development.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Revenue Sharing Undermines Profitability
keyConcerns.description: This provision requires **certified cybersecurity professionals to surrender 30% of their revenue** to the cybersecurity fund while charging only **government-mandated flat rates** set by the Authority. This creates a business environment where the regulatory authority controls both pricing and extracts substantial revenue from the market it regulates—a **financial conflict of interest** that concentrates power and reduces business profitability. Combined with licensing requirements in [17](#17-section-57a-inserted) and [18](#18-section-57b-inserted), this creates **high barriers to market entry** and eliminates pricing flexibility that businesses need to compete and differentiate services.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Certification Stifles Tech Innovation
keyConcerns.description: This provision requires **certification for all emerging technologies** (AI, cloud, quantum computing, big data, blockchain) without defining what certification means, who needs it, or what exemptions exist. Combined with [23](#23-section-59a-inserted)'s **criminal penalties** (up to 5 years imprisonment) for operating without accreditation, this creates a mandatory pre-market approval regime that **blocks experimentation and market entry**. Unlike democratic precedents (EU AI Act), there are **no exemptions for research, non-commercial use, or small providers**—and no procedural safeguards, transparency requirements, or appeal mechanisms. This grants the Authority unconstrained gatekeeping power over Ghana's digital economy, creating insurmountable barriers for startups and researchers while established players absorb compliance costs.

keyConcerns.title: Criminal Penalties Deter Market Entry
keyConcerns.description: This provision makes it a **criminal offense punishable by up to 5 years imprisonment** to provide cybersecurity services without a license or act as a cybersecurity professional without accreditation. This goes far beyond standard regulatory practice—most democracies treat licensing violations as administrative matters with fines, not criminal imprisonment. For digital innovation, this creates an **absolute barrier to market entry**: startups cannot test services, researchers cannot conduct vulnerability research, and individual practitioners cannot operate informally before obtaining licenses. The **vague directive-based offenses** (criminalizing failure to comply with Authority directives) create additional uncertainty—innovators cannot know what conduct is criminal because it depends on executive directives that can change. Combined with the comprehensive licensing regime covering all cybersecurity providers, this will **substantially deter entrepreneurship and shift innovation to established licensed entities**, reducing competition and slowing innovation cycles in Ghana's cybersecurity sector.

keyConcerns.title: Vague Offenses Enable Arbitrary Enforcement
keyConcerns.description: This provision makes it a **criminal offense** (up to 5 years imprisonment) to "knowingly fail to comply with...directives issued under this Act"—but directives are executive instruments issued by the Authority itself, not parliamentary legislation. Businesses cannot know in advance what conduct is criminal since it depends on Authority directives that can change. The provision grants the Authority **unfettered discretion** to pursue "only criminal enforcement actions...or only administration enforcement actions...or a combination of both" without standards for when each applies, enabling selective enforcement. Combined with [24](#24-section-59b-inserted)'s grant of prosecution powers, the Authority becomes investigator, prosecutor, and beneficiary (fines fund its operations), creating conflicts of interest and operational uncertainty for businesses.

keyConcerns.title: Criminalizing "False Information" Threatens Speech
keyConcerns.description: Subsection (6) criminalizes spreading **"false or misleading information with the intent to deceive or manipulate a person or a fact"** with penalties of 1-3 years imprisonment. This extraordinarily broad language could capture **satire, political commentary, journalism, academic debate, and opinion**—all protected speech categories under international human rights law. The phrase "manipulate a person or a fact" is dangerously vague, potentially criminalizing persuasion or advocacy. Combined with vague definitions of **"offensive," "rude," and "insulting"** messages in the cyberbullying definition, this provision creates severe **chilling effects on legitimate expression** while granting authorities wide discretion to determine what constitutes prohibited speech.

keyConcerns.title: Undefined "False Information" Chills Innovation
keyConcerns.description: This provision criminalizes **"creating false information about a person"** with penalties up to **10 years imprisonment**, but fails to define what constitutes "false information." This creates severe uncertainty for digital platforms, AI developers, and emerging technology companies who cannot determine what content violates the law. The provision explicitly applies to **virtual, augmented and mixed reality platforms**—technologies that inherently involve fictional identities and scenarios—potentially criminalizing core features of immersive technologies. Without safe harbors for satire, opinion, good-faith errors, or algorithmic content, platforms face pressure to over-moderate, startups face existential legal risk, and innovation in content creation, AI systems, and virtual worlds is substantially chilled.

keyConcerns.title: Undefined "Cyberstalking" Creates Business Liability
keyConcerns.description: This provision criminalizes "cyberstalking" including creating or disseminating **"false information about a person"** with penalties of 1-10 years imprisonment, but fails to define critical terms like "harass," "stalk," or "false information." This creates **severe compliance uncertainty** for businesses operating online platforms, communication services, or digital businesses—companies cannot develop clear content moderation policies or determine what user conduct violates the law. The **broad scope** captures legitimate business communications including customer reviews, competitive analysis, and commercial speech, while the **severe penalties** (up to 10 years) pressure platforms toward aggressive over-moderation. The provision overlaps with the preceding cyberbullying offense [35](#35-section-67a-inserted) but with higher penalties, creating **prosecutorial discretion** that compounds business uncertainty and raises operational costs.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Minimums Deter Digital Innovation
keyConcerns.description: This provision establishes **mandatory minimum sentences of 3-10 years imprisonment** for cybercrimes, removing judicial discretion to impose proportionate penalties. When combined with the vague "false information" offenses in [36](#36-section-67b-inserted), this creates **extreme legal risk for digital platforms and startups** hosting user-generated content. The mandatory minimums exceed international norms (OECD democracies typically allow 2-5 year maximums with judicial discretion) and create a **risk-averse environment that deters legitimate online services**, particularly platforms involving AI-generated content, social features, or data analysis where the boundaries of criminal liability are unclear.

keyConcerns.title: Harsh Penalties Chill Online Speech
keyConcerns.description: This provision establishes **mandatory minimum sentences of 3-10 years imprisonment** for cybercrimes, including offenses defined in [36](#36-section-67b-inserted) such as "creating false information" or "posting false information." The **3-year mandatory minimum** removes judicial discretion to consider whether speech was mistaken versus malicious, opinion versus fact, or satire versus defamation. Combined with vague offense definitions, these severe penalties will **chill legitimate online expression**—journalists, whistleblowers, political critics, and ordinary citizens face potential imprisonment for speech that would be protected or subject only to civil remedies in most democracies. The mandatory minimum prevents proportionate sentencing and exceeds international norms for speech-related offenses.

keyConcerns.title: Severe Penalties Create Business Uncertainty
keyConcerns.description: This provision establishes **mandatory minimum sentences of 3-10 years imprisonment** and fines of **250-25,000 penalty units** for cybercrimes, but operates in conjunction with [36](#36-section-67b-inserted)'s vague offense definitions including "creating false information." For digital businesses—particularly platforms hosting user-generated content, e-commerce sites, and data analytics companies—this creates **severe legal uncertainty** about when operations might trigger criminal liability. The mandatory minimums eliminate judicial discretion to account for offense severity or business context, forcing businesses to invest heavily in risk-averse compliance systems or avoid the Ghanaian market entirely. This penalty structure **significantly exceeds international norms** (most OECD democracies impose 2-5 year maximums), creating competitive disadvantages for Ghanaian digital businesses and deterring foreign investment in Ghana's digital economy.

keyConcerns.title: Emergency Data Disclosure Without Judicial Review
keyConcerns.description: This provision permits **expedited disclosure of stored computer data** in emergency situations without requiring **judicial authorization, proportionality assessment, or notice to data subjects**. While the emergency definition is narrow (significant risk to life/safety), the absence of procedural safeguards creates risk of overreach. International privacy frameworks like **GDPR and the Budapest Convention** recognize emergency exceptions but require either prior court approval or subsequent review, proportionality assessment, and documentation—none of which are mandated here.

keyConcerns.title: Unconstrained Technology Mandate Authority
keyConcerns.description: The provision grants the Authority power to regulate "**safeguarding the development and deployment of innovative and emerging technologies**" with no defined scope or standards. Combined with [41](#41-section-92-of-act-1038-amended)'s directive powers over "innovators, developers," this enables the Authority to **mandate specific technology approaches** or prohibit innovations without parliamentary oversight. The catch-all clause "**any other matter required for ensuring cybersecurity**" allows unlimited regulatory expansion. This creates legal uncertainty that chills innovation and lacks the consultation requirements, cost-benefit analysis, and appeals mechanisms standard in OECD technology regulation.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Licensing Creates Market Barriers
keyConcerns.description: This provision establishes **mandatory licensing for cybersecurity service providers** and **accreditation requirements for professionals** (items k, l, o, p), creating significant barriers to market entry and ongoing compliance costs. Combined with penalties of **50,000-100,000 penalty units** for operating without licenses ([15](#15-section-49-of-act-1038-amended)), this extends professional regulation beyond what is typical in democracies—where licensing is reserved for professions with direct public safety implications. The **catch-all clause** "(p) any other matter required for ensuring cybersecurity" allows indefinite expansion of regulatory requirements without parliamentary oversight, creating legal uncertainty for business planning and disproportionately affecting small businesses and startups.

keyConcerns.title: Unchecked Directives Threaten Innovation
keyConcerns.description: The Authority gains **broad power to issue directives to innovators and developers** regarding "adoption and deployment of innovative and emerging technologies" without defining what these directives can require, what standards apply, or what procedural safeguards exist. This creates **severe regulatory uncertainty** for technology companies: they cannot predict what compliance requirements they may face when developing new solutions, and they have **no notice, hearing, or appeal rights** before directives are imposed. The provision could enable the Authority to mandate specific technology choices, implementation approaches, or security standards without technical justification, potentially forcing innovators to adopt solutions that are technically suboptimal or commercially disadvantageous. This **regulatory unpredictability** may deter companies from developing or deploying innovative technologies in Ghana, particularly in emerging areas like AI, blockchain, and quantum computing that the bill explicitly targets for regulation.

keyConcerns.title: Undefined Directive Power Creates Compliance Chaos
keyConcerns.description: The Authority gains **sweeping power to issue directives** to critical infrastructure owners, service providers, cybersecurity providers, innovators, and developers—but the provision never defines what "directives" are, what they can require, or what penalties apply for non-compliance. Businesses face **regulatory uncertainty** as they cannot predict what compliance obligations may be imposed, when, or through what process. With **no notice, hearing, or appeal rights** specified, the Authority can unilaterally impose operational requirements, technology mandates, or reporting obligations without demonstrating necessity or considering business impact, creating unpredictable compliance costs across Ghana's technology sector.

keyConcerns.title: No Safe Harbor for Security Research
keyConcerns.description: This provision criminalizes **unauthorized access** to computer systems and critical infrastructure (2-5 years imprisonment, up to 25,000 penalty units) without defining what constitutes "lawful authority" or providing **explicit exemptions for security researchers**, penetration testers, or bug bounty participants. Combined with the Authority's directive power over "innovators, developers" ([41](#41-section-92-of-act-1038-amended)), this creates a regime where security researchers face criminal liability unless they obtain explicit Authority approval before testing—**chilling legitimate vulnerability research** and responsible disclosure practices that are essential to cybersecurity innovation.

keyConcerns.title: Undefined "Lawful Authority" Creates Business Liability
keyConcerns.description: The provision criminalizes accessing subscriber information, traffic data, or critical infrastructure **"without lawful authority"** but fails to define what constitutes lawful authority for routine business operations. Businesses conducting **security testing, system administration, employee access management, or third-party audits** face criminal liability (2-5 years imprisonment, up to 25,000 penalty units) unless they can demonstrate authorization—yet the provision provides no guidance on what documentation or processes establish "lawful authority." This creates **substantial compliance costs** as businesses must implement comprehensive access control systems and authorization documentation to avoid criminal exposure, while the provision's treatment of **attempts and successful access identically** means even unsuccessful employee or contractor access triggers liability.

provisions.title: Section 3 of Act 1038 Amended
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision outlines the goals of the Cybersecurity Authority, which include overseeing cybersecurity practices and addressing threats. It aims to regulate key information infrastructure and promote a secure digital environment. The Authority will also work to prevent cybercrime, seize related illegal gains, foster collaboration between public and private sectors, raise awareness about cybersecurity, and partner with international organizations.
provisions.impactReasoning:
This provision amends Section 3 of the Cybersecurity Act to redefine the Authority's objects (core purposes). The current provision itself is procedural and foundational—it establishes the Authority's mandate without creating specific operational requirements, enforcement mechanisms, or restrictions. The substantive impacts arise from how these objects are operationalized through the following provisions (particularly Section 4A on functions).

**Assessment of the current provision in isolation:**

The amended Section 3 expands the Authority's stated objects from a narrower regulatory focus to include law enforcement functions (prevent and detect cybercrime, facilitate confiscation). Key objects include:
- Regulating cybersecurity activities, service providers, professionals, and critical infrastructure owners
- Preventing, managing, and responding to cybersecurity threats
- Preventing and detecting cybercrime
- Facilitating confiscation of proceeds of cybercrime
- Promoting cybersecurity development and digital ecosystem resilience
- Cross-sector engagement and international collaboration
- Awareness and digital rights protection

**Digital Innovation Impact:**
The provision's direct language is neutral-to-positive on innovation. Objects (b), (d), and (g) explicitly promote cybersecurity development, digital ecosystem resilience, and cross-sector engagement. However, the impact depends critically on how object (c)—regulating service providers, professionals, and establishments—is implemented. The following provision (Section 4A) reveals that implementation includes mandatory accreditation and certification schemes. The current provision itself does not impose these requirements; it merely establishes the Authority's mandate to regulate. The provision does not create barriers or compliance burdens directly—those emerge from operational provisions. The explicit mention of promoting development and resilience is mildly positive.

**Freedom of Speech Impact:**
The current provision has minimal direct impact on freedom of speech. Object (e) addresses cybercrime prevention (which may include speech-related crimes like cyberbullying, addressed elsewhere in the bill), but the provision itself does not restrict speech or establish content moderation requirements. The provision is neutral on its face, though the broader bill's criminalization of cyberbullying and online harassment (Sections 67A-67B) raises speech concerns that are not present in this foundational provision.

**Privacy & Data Rights Impact:**
Object (f) explicitly includes facilitating confiscation of proceeds of cybercrime, which relates to asset recovery but not directly to data protection or privacy rights. The provision does not establish data collection, retention, or access requirements. It does not weaken or strengthen privacy protections directly. The provision is neutral on its face, though the following provision (Section 4A) and other sections establish investigative tools that do implicate privacy.

**Business Environment Impact:**
The current provision establishes a regulatory mandate but does not directly impose compliance burdens. Object (c) indicates the Authority will regulate service providers, professionals, and establishments, but the provision does not specify licensing requirements, fees, or operational restrictions. These emerge from subsequent provisions. The provision's language on promoting development and cross-sector engagement is mildly positive for business environment. However, the regulatory mandate itself signals that compliance obligations will follow, creating some uncertainty about future operational costs.

**Relationship to following provision:**
Section 4A operationalizes these objects by specifying functions including investigation/prosecution, certification standards, accreditation of service providers and professionals, and protection of vulnerable populations. The current provision's object (c) regarding regulation of service providers and professionals directly enables Section 4A's accreditation and certification functions. The current provision's object (e) regarding cybercrime prevention directly enables Section 4A's investigation and prosecution function. The relationship is functional but not problematic—the current provision establishes the mandate; Section 4A specifies how it will be exercised.

**Overall assessment:**
This is a foundational, procedural provision that establishes the Authority's mandate. It does not itself create specific operational requirements, restrictions, or enforcement mechanisms. The provision is broadly framed and includes both regulatory and developmental objectives. The language promoting cybersecurity development, digital ecosystem resilience, and digital rights protection is mildly positive. The regulatory mandate is standard for sector regulators. The provision does not violate rule of law principles—it clearly establishes the Authority's scope and purposes. However, the provision's impact depends entirely on implementation through subsequent provisions, which do create compliance burdens and enforcement mechanisms.

The provision itself warrants neutral-to-low-positive ratings because:
1. It establishes a clear, legally certain mandate (rule of law positive)
2. It includes explicit objectives for development and resilience (innovation positive)
3. It does not directly impose restrictions, licensing requirements, or compliance burdens
4. It does not directly restrict speech or weaken privacy protections
5. The regulatory mandate is standard for cybersecurity authorities in democratic jurisdictions

However, confidence is moderate (not high) because the provision's practical impact depends on how subsequent provisions operationalize these objects, and some of those provisions (accreditation, certification, confiscation) do create concerns addressed in other assessments.

provisions.title: Section 4A inserted
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision expands the Authority's role to include investigating and prosecuting cybercrimes with the Attorney-General's approval. It also tasks the Authority with setting security standards and certifying innovative technologies like AI and blockchain. Additionally, the Authority will accredit cybersecurity entities, promote online safety for vulnerable groups, and work to protect digital rights in the cybersecurity space.
provisions.impactReasoning:
This provision expands the Cybersecurity Authority's functions from regulatory oversight to include investigation, prosecution, certification, and accreditation powers. The assessment must evaluate each functional component:

**1. Investigation and Prosecution (4A(a)):**
The provision subjects prosecution authority to Article 88 of Ghana's Constitution and Attorney-General approval, establishing constitutional guardrails. This creates a separation-of-powers mechanism where the Authority investigates but cannot unilaterally prosecute—requiring AG authorization. This is a standard prosecutorial oversight model found in many democracies. However, combining investigation and prosecution powers in a single agency (even with AG approval) concentrates enforcement authority, though the constitutional reference and AG requirement provide meaningful checks.

**2. Certification and Standards (4A(b)-(c)):**
The Authority establishes and implements security standards for emerging technologies (AI, blockchain, quantum computing, big data, IoT). This is a standard regulatory function comparable to technical standard-setting bodies in OECD countries (e.g., NIST in the US, BSI in Germany). The provision itself does not mandate licensing or create barriers—it establishes technical standards. However, when read with the bill context indicating mandatory licensing for cybersecurity service providers and professionals, this standard-setting becomes part of a broader licensing regime that creates compliance burdens.

**3. Accreditation Powers (4A(d)-(e)):**
The provision grants accreditation authority over cybersecurity establishments, service providers, practitioners, professionals, and non-profit institutions. Accreditation differs from licensing—it certifies competence rather than restricting market entry. However, the bill context indicates that engaging unaccredited professionals triggers penalties (Section 57), converting accreditation into a de facto licensing requirement. This creates a significant barrier to market entry for cybersecurity services, which are typically unregulated in most OECD democracies.

**4. Protective and Collaborative Functions (4A(f)-(h)):**
Promoting online protection for vulnerable groups and digital rights are beneficial functions aligned with international standards (GDPR, ICCPR). These create no direct negative impacts.

**Key Contextual Issues:**

The provision must be assessed against the bill context showing:
- Mandatory licensing/accreditation for all cybersecurity service providers (Section 49)
- Individual professional accreditation requirements (Section 57)
- Penalties for engaging unaccredited professionals
- Revenue-sharing requirements (30% of certified professionals' revenue to cybersecurity fund)

**Rule of Law Analysis:**

*Positive aspects:*
- Constitutional reference (Article 88) provides legal certainty
- AG approval requirement for prosecution creates separation of powers
- Standard-setting and accreditation are legitimate regulatory functions

*Concerns:*
- Concentration of investigation, prosecution, and standard-setting in single agency (though mitigated by AG requirement)
- Accreditation converted to de facto licensing creates barriers to market entry for cybersecurity services
- No explicit appeal or review mechanisms mentioned in this provision for accreditation decisions
- Undefined standards for accreditation ("in accordance with standards established pursuant to paragraph (b)") creates potential for arbitrary enforcement

**Digital Innovation Impact:**
The provision establishes certification schemes for emerging technologies (AI, blockchain, quantum computing, big data, IoT), which could facilitate innovation by providing security assurance. However, when combined with mandatory accreditation and licensing requirements in the bill context, this creates significant compliance burdens and market entry barriers. The certification function itself is neutral-to-positive, but the accreditation requirement (4A(d)-(e)) combined with penalties for non-compliance creates barriers typical of high-negative regulatory regimes. The provision does not explicitly require use of government infrastructure or create unprecedented barriers, but it does establish a comprehensive licensing/accreditation regime for services typically unregulated in democracies.

**Freedom of Speech Impact:**
The provision has minimal direct impact on freedom of speech. The protective functions (4A(f)-(h)) regarding vulnerable groups and digital rights are beneficial. However, the investigation and prosecution authority (4A(a)) combined with the bill's cyberbullying and online harassment provisions (Sections 67A-67B) could create chilling effects on online expression, though this is primarily driven by the criminal provisions rather than this functional expansion.

**Privacy & Data Rights Impact:**
The provision itself does not directly regulate data handling. However, the accreditation and certification functions could establish privacy standards for emerging technologies. The investigation authority (4A(a)) combined with investigative tools in other provisions (data production orders, search warrants, preservation orders) creates surveillance capabilities. This provision alone is neutral, but in context of the full bill's investigative powers, it enables privacy-impacting enforcement.

**Business Environment Impact:**
The accreditation and licensing requirements (4A(d)-(e)) create significant compliance burdens and market entry barriers for cybersecurity service providers and professionals. This is a high-negative impact on business environment, as it restricts market participation in services typically unregulated in OECD democracies. The certification schemes for emerging technologies could facilitate innovation but are offset by the mandatory accreditation requirements. The revenue-sharing requirement (30% of certified professionals' revenue) creates additional operational costs.

**Confidence Assessment:**
High confidence (0.85) because:
- The provision's language is relatively clear
- The functional components are well-defined
- The bill context provides substantial detail on implementation
- The impacts on each topic area are reasonably determinable
- Some uncertainty remains regarding how accreditation standards will be applied in practice and whether appeal mechanisms exist (not specified in this provision)

**Overall Assessment:**
This provision represents a significant expansion of the Authority's powers, combining regulatory, investigative, and prosecutorial functions. While the constitutional reference and AG approval requirement provide some checks, the accreditation and licensing requirements create substantial barriers to market entry for cybersecurity services. The provision is most problematic when combined with the bill's mandatory licensing regime and penalty provisions.

provisions.title: Section 5 of Act 1038 amended
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision modifies a section of Act 1038 to include "Foreign Affairs and Regional Integration" and "Gender, Children and Social Protection" in a specific list. The change expands the scope of the list to formally include these two areas. The specific impact of this change depends on the context of the original section in Act 1038.

provisions.impactReasoning:
This provision amends Section 5 of Act 1038 to expand the composition of the Cyber Security Authority's governing board by adding two new ministerial representatives: Foreign Affairs and Regional Integration, and Gender, Children and Social Protection.

**Direct Assessment of Current Provision:**

The current provision is a procedural/structural amendment that adds two ministerial representatives to the Authority's board composition. This is a governance structure change, not a substantive policy change.

**Governance Structure Analysis:**

1. **Board Composition Expansion**: The addition of Foreign Affairs and Regional Integration aligns with international cybersecurity governance norms, as cross-border cyber threats require diplomatic coordination. The addition of Gender, Children and Social Protection reflects the bill's stated focus on protecting vulnerable populations (women, elderly, persons with disabilities, children) as articulated in Section 4A(f).

2. **Institutional Representation**: Adding these ministries to the board creates broader stakeholder representation in Authority decision-making, which enhances democratic accountability and ensures diverse perspectives in cybersecurity policy.

3. **Separation of Powers Consideration**: The following provision (Section 13) shows that the board includes representatives from Data Protection Commission, National Intelligence Bureau, and National Signals Bureau. The addition of Foreign Affairs and Gender/Social Protection ministries continues this multi-stakeholder model rather than concentrating power in a single entity.

4. **Potential Concerns**: 
   - The provision doesn't specify voting rights, quorum requirements, or conflict resolution mechanisms for the expanded board
   - No explicit safeguards prevent political interference in technical cybersecurity decisions
   - The board's expanded size could slow decision-making, though this is a minor procedural concern

**Context from Adjacent Provisions:**

- Section 4A establishes the Authority's expanded functions including investigation, prosecution, certification, and accreditation
- Section 13 (following provision) shows the board already includes intelligence and data protection representatives, suggesting this is part of a broader institutional design for multi-stakeholder oversight
- The addition of Gender, Children and Social Protection directly supports Section 4A(f)'s mandate to promote online protection of vulnerable populations

**Impact Assessment:**

This provision has minimal direct impact on the core policy areas. It is a structural governance amendment that:
- Does not create new substantive powers or restrictions
- Does not directly affect digital innovation, speech, privacy, or business operations
- Enhances institutional representation and accountability through board diversification
- Supports the bill's stated protective objectives for vulnerable populations

The provision represents standard good governance practice (multi-stakeholder representation) without introducing novel risks or benefits. It is procedurally sound and aligns with democratic principles of inclusive institutional design.

provisions.title: Section 13 of Act 1038 amended
provisions.plainLanguage: This section modifies the composition and operation of the Joint Cybersecurity Committee. It updates the titles of member organizations, allows for the nomination of representatives with cybersecurity expertise, and permits the Minister to appoint additional members. The amendment also establishes rules for membership termination due to absenteeism and outlines the process for filling vacancies.
provisions.rawText:
- The principal enactment is amended in section 13 by:

  - (a) the substitution for paragraph (d) of subsection (2), of

    - '(d) the Executive Director of the Data Protection Commission or any successor  official  or  entity  by  whatever  name  designated,  or  a representative of the Executive Director with the requisite knowledge  and  skills  in cybercrime  and  cybersecurity  matters, nominated by the Executive Director;';
